Exercise 5.4: Problem 2 (part h)
Problem 2: We will now derive the probability that a given observation is part of a bootstrap sample. Suppose that we obtain a bootstrap sample from a set of ğ‘› observations.

(g) Create a plot that displays, for each integer value of ğ‘› from 1 to 100, 000, the probability that the ğ‘—th observation is in the bootstrap sample. Comment on what you observe.

```{r}
x=seq(1,100000)
y=1-((1-(1/x))^x)
plot(x,y,xlab="n")
#as n gets larger, the probability converges to approximately 0.62
```
(h) We will now investigate numerically the probability that a bootstrap sample of size ğ‘›=100 contains the ğ‘—th observation. Here ğ‘—=4. We repeatedly create bootstrap samples, and each time we record whether or not the fourth observation is contained in the bootstrap sample.
```{r}
store=rep(NA, 10000)

for(i in 1:10000) { store[i]=sum(sample (1:100, rep=TRUE)==4) >0

}

mean(store)
#This result is really close to what we get at question g
```

Comment on the results obtained.
